questions.text:
Mark the correct actions of the muscle marked 'X':-
A. Flexion at hip joint
B. Extension at knee joint
C. Medial rotation of thigh
D. Abduction of thigh
E. Flexion at knee joint
Choose the correct combination:-
questions.solution:
Muscle is Sartorius as it origins from anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) and inserts on pes anserine.

It has following actions

  • Flexion at hip joint
  • Flexion at knee joint
  • Abduction of thigh
  • Lateral rotation of thigh.

Ref. BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 2

Section 1 lower limb Chapter 3 front of thigh page no. 62

questions.text:
Choose the correct type of joints
a) Synarthrosis (Fibrous joint)
b) Synchondrosis
c) Secondary cartilaginous joint
d) Plane synovial joint
Choose the correct combination of matching
questions.solution:
Midline joints like Manubriosternal & xiphisternal joints are secondary cartilaginous (symphysis) type.

  1. Costochondral joints are primary cartilaginous type (synchondrosis)
  2. 1st sternocostal joint- Synarthrosis (fibrous)
  3. Joint between 8th & 9th rib to 7th rib are interchondral joint of plane synovial variety.

Most of the joints of thoracic cavity like costovertebral, costotransverse, sternocostal, interchondral are plane synovial joints because the thoracic cavity needs to expand during inspiration. Above given examples are the exceptions to it.

Ref. BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 1

1. Anterior cruciate ligament
2. Posterior cruciate ligament
3. Anterior part of Medial meniscus
4. Posterior part of medial meniscus
5. Anterior part of lateral meniscus
6. Posterior part of lateral meniscus
questions.solution:
Remember this by a simple mnemonic :

Medical – anterior limb of medial meniscus

College – ACL

Lucknow – (Anterior limb) Lateral meniscus

Lucknow – (Posterior limb) Lateral menisucs

Medical – (posterior limb) medial meniscus

College – PCL

questions.text: A 34-year-old female presents to emergency department with severe nausea and recurrent bilious vomiting Her symptoms initially began as postprandial epigastric pain and early satiety, but have progressed over the last two weeks. She works as an model and her symptoms only started when she was inspired to lose 10kg weight on a 'crash diet'. On physical exam her abdomen is tender and slightly distended with high-pitched bowel sounds. A laparotomy is performed and it is observed that the angle between her superior mesenteric artery and her aorta is significantly decreased. Which of the following structures is most likely to be obstructed by the artery?
questions.solution:
The superior mesenteric artery (SMA) leaves the aorta at the level of L1 and supplies the intestine from the duodenum and pancreas to the left colic flexure the transverse portion of the duodenum lies horizontally at the level of L3. Between the aorta and superior mesenteric artery normally, the SMA and aorta form an approximately 45 degree angle. If this angle diminishes to less than 20 degrees the transverse portion of the duodenum can get entrapped between the SMA and aorta leading to symptoms of partial small bowel obstruction. This condition is called superior mesenteric artery syndrome.

Narrowing of the aortomesenteric angle can occur with any condition that causes diminished mesenteric fat, including low body weight, recent weight loss, severe burns or other inducers of catabolism, and prolonged bed rest It can also occur with pronounced lordosis or after surgical correction of scoliosis, as this procedure lengthens the spine resulting in decreased mobility of the SMA.

Ref. BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 2

Section 1 ABDOMEN AND PELVIS Chapter 20 SMALL AND LARGE INTESTINES and brain page no. 309

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy is brought to the urology clinic for follow-up of an undescended right testicle discovered in the newbom nursery. Examination shows absence of a palpable right testis in the scrotal sac. However, a round mass is palpated superior to the scrotum in the inguinal canal Orchiopexy is recommended to the family. During this procedure, the malpositioned testis will most likely be pulled through a physiologic opening in which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Testicles develop in the fetal abdomen during organogenesis Between 8 weeks and full term, each testis descends from the abdomen into the inguinal canal through the deep inguinal ring, which is an opening in the transversalis fascia bounded laterally by the transversus abdominis muscle and medially by the inferior epigastric vessels

Each testis then passes anteromedially through the canal and enters the scrotum via the superficial inguinal ring, which is a physiologic opening in the external oblique muscle aponeurosis above the pubic tubercle.

Cryptorchidism is the failure of one or both testes to descend to the scrotum before birth which occurs, more commonly in preterm neonates. It is associated with a significantly increased risk of testicular cancer and infertility A testis that is palpable in the inguinal canal typically descends spontaneously by age 6 months. Testes that have not descended by this point are unlikely to do so and require surgical intervention (ie. orchiopexy).

In this case the patient's undescended testicle is lodged within the Inguinal canal and must be mobilized through the superficial inguinal ring and stitched into place in the scrotum

(Choice A) The conjoint tendon is the common tendon of the transversus abdominis and internal oblique muscles. It forms part of the posterior wall of the inguinal canal.

(Option C) The femoral ring is a physiologic opening between the abdominal cavity and the femoral canal. It transmits lymphatic vessels but not the spermatic cord.

(Option D) The internal oblique muscle aponeurosis contributes to the formation of the conjoint tendon and rectus muscle sheath In addition the cremaster muscle originates from the internal oblique muscle itself.

questions.text: A patient recovering from a traumatic injury to the face now finds himself unable to chew his food. On physical examination, his jaw deviates to the right side. The nerve that has been injured in this patient exits the skull through which of the following foramina?
questions.solution:
• Muscles of mastication are involved in the given condition.
  • All the muscles of mastication are supplied by mandibular nerve.
  • Mandibular nerve passes through foramen ovale.
  • Structures passing through foramen ovale (MALE)
    • Mandibular Nerve
    • Accessory meningeal artery
    • Lesser Petrosal Nerve
    • Emissary veins

questions.text: A 43 year old woman came with a large abscess in the middle of the right posterior triangle of the neck. The physician incised and drained the abscess. Five days later the patient noticed that she could not extend her right hand above her head to brush her hair. Which of the following are the signs and symptoms of additional harm -
questions.solution:
• Superficial cut in the region of middle part of posterior triangle of neck will lead to injury to Spinal Accessory nerve, hence muscle supplied by it (trapezius) is paralysed. Therefore Shrugging of shoulder and Overhead Abduction of arm (for combing of hair) will be affected.

questions.text: The main muscle associated with positive trendelenburg sign is attached to?
questions.solution:
Trendelenburg's sign: When both feet are supporting the body weight, horizontal level of pelvis is maintained (i.e., anterior superior iliac spines lie in the same horizontal plane);

When only one foot is supporting the body weight, the unsupported side of the pelvis is normally raised or prevented from sagging by the opposite gluteus medius and minimus muscles;

If the gluteus medius and minimus muscles are paralyzed on one side the unsupported left side of pelvis sags (this is positive Trendelenburg's sign).

Gluteus medius is the main abductor of hip and it originates from dorsal surface of ileum and inserted on the lateral surface of greater trochanter.

Ref. BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 2

Section 1 lower limb Chapter 5 GLUTEAL REGION and page no. 81

questions.text: Patient present with ipsilateral paralysis of soft palate with loss of temperature and sensation on same side of face and Loss of pain and temperature on opposite side of the body. This clinical symptoms seen in which of the following syndromes?
questions.solution:
Lateral medullary/Wallenburg syndrome: Occurs due to blockage of posterior inferior cerebellar artery. It supplies areas behind the inferior olivary nucleus.

Features are:

  1. Ipsilateral paralysis of most of muscles of soft palate, pharynx and larynx due to injury to nucleus ambiguus which gives fibres to IX, X and XI cranial nerves
  2. Loss of pain and temperature on same side of face due to involvement of spinal nucleus and spinal tract of trigeminal nerve.
  3. Loss of pain and temperature on opposite side of the body due to involvement of lateral spinothalamic tract
  4. Giddiness due to involvement of vestibular nuclei.
  5. Damage to inferior cerebellar peduncle, spinocerebellar tracts and part of cerebellum results in loss of equilibrium, i.e. ataxia of limbs on the same side.
  6. The sympathetic fibres descend from hypothalamus to cells in lateral horn of spinal cord. As these fibers descend in the lateral part of medulla (which is damaged), there is Horner’s syndrome, comprising ptosis, enophthalmos, miosis and anhydrosis

Ref. BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 4

questions.text:
In the popliteal fossa which is of the following statements is True/false -
A.The popliteal fossa is bounded above by tendons of the hamstring muscles and below by the two heads of the gastrocnemius muscle
B. The deepest structure in the popliteal fossa is the popliteal artery
C. The popliteal and femoral vessels are continuous through the adductor hiatus
D.The common peroneal nerve passes superficially through the central protion of popliteal fossa
questions.solution:
• The common peroneal nerve appears in the popliteal fossa beneath the long head of the biceps femoris and slopes downward and laterally along the medial side of the tendon of biceps femoris up to the lateral angle of the fossa.
  • Here it crosses superficial to the plantaris, lateral head of gastrocnemius to reach the back of the head of fibula. it passes superficially through the central portion of popliteal fossa.
  • The Sciatic & Tibial nerve passes superficially through the central portion of popliteal fossa

questions.text: Arterial supply of motor area of cerebral cortex is:
questions.solution:
Anterior and middle cerebral artery

  • Motor area (4) is present in the precentral gyrus (frontal lobe).
  • Frontal lobe receives blood supply mainly from middle cerebral artery and partly from the anterior cerebral artery.
  • Middle cerebral territory in on the lateral surface, while anterior cerebral supplies a narrow strip close to the superior midline fissure

questions.text: The reflex arc of jaw jerk is integrated at which nucleus of the trigeminal nuclei?
questions.solution:
Trigeminal nuclei:

Midbrain – mesencephalic nucleus = proprioception + jaw jerk

Pons – principal nucleus = touch and pressure

Medulla – spinal nucleus = pain and temperature

questions.text: Inability to abduct left eye with LMN facial palsy on same side. The lesion is in:
questions.solution:
Left pons

  • The abducent nucleus is present in the pons along with facial nucleus and both are damaged here.
  • These nuclei contain the lower motor neurons and hence the lesion here gives ipsilateral signs Hence, the lesion in the left pons leads to left facial palsy and inability to abduct the left eye laterally

Ref. BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 4

Brain and neuroanatomy Chapter 5 brainstem page no. 109

choices.text: Lower part of pons near facial nucleus

questions.text: Principal Sensory Nucleus of Trigeminal is situated at:
questions.solution:
• Trigeminal nerve has 4 nuclei & ndash;3 sensory and 1 motor.
  • 3 sensory nuclei are mesencephalicnucleus, chief sensory nucleus and spinal nucleus.
  • Chief sensory nucleus will be in upper part of pons
  • Spinal nucleus of the trigeminal extends inferiorly into the medulla oblongata, whereas Mesencephalic nucleus extends into the mid - brain.

The trigeminal nerve is attached to this surface at the junction of the pons with the peduncle. The nerve has two roots-a small motor root which lies medial to the much larger sensory root. The attached abducent, facial and vestibulocochlear nerves are at the lower border of the ventral surface at the junction of pons and medulla oblongata.

questions.text: Following statements describe the cells of cerebellar cortex. Choose the wrong statement:
questions.solution:
Granule cells receive afferent inhibitory fibers termed as mossy fibers

Mossy fibres are excitatory fibres, stimulating the Granule cells.

Granule cells then send the parallel fibres which will stimulate the remaining4 cell types of the cerebellar cortex.

questions.text: A patient has lost the ability to discriminate between two points presented simultaneously to the skin of the left hand. Neurological evaluation is most likely to reveal a lesion in the:
questions.solution:
Medial lemniscus on the right side of the pons

  • Two point discrimination is carried by the dorsal column-medial lemniscal system
  • Dorsal column runs ipsilaterally, while medial lemniscus runs contralateral
  • So, if medial lemniscus is lesioned on the right side, the loss of two point discrimination will be lost on the left side, as observed in this patient.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a branch of external carotid artery in Kisselbach plexus?
questions.solution:
Kiesselbach's plexus is formed by:

  • Septal branch of the anterior ethmoidal artery (a branch of ophthalmic artery).
  • Septal branch of the sphenopalatine artery (a branch of maxillary artery).
  • Septal branch of the greater palatine artery (a branch of maxillary artery).
  • Septal branch of the superior labial artery (a branch of facial artery)

Ant. and post. ethmoidal are branches of INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY

Maxillary and facial are branches of ECA.

Sphenopalatine artery is 'artery of epistaxis'.

Ref. BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 3

questions.text: A 45 year old male is brought to emergency department following a RTA. He is having maxillofacial injury. Surgical repair is performed and condition is stabilised. After repair patient develops difficulty chewing food. O/E when patient is instructed to open his mouth, jaw deviates to the right side. The nerve that has been injured in this patient exist through which of the following foramina?
questions.solution:
This patient has symptoms consistent with injury to the third division of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve (CN] V3, mandibular nerve), which provides sensory innervation to the face and motor innervation to the muscles of mastication. These include the 3 muscles that elevate the jaw (masseter medial pterygoid, temporalis) and the single muscle that depress the jaw (lateral pterygoid)

Unilateral injury to CN V3 will result in unopposed action of the contralateral pterygoid muscles which leads to deviation of the mandible toward the paralyzed side on opening the mouth. B/L paralysis would cause mandibular drop and lack of jaw movement.

CN V3 exits the skull through the foramen ovale .

The second division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V2, maxillary nerve exits the skull via the foramen rotundum (option C)

The foramen spinosum contains the middle meningeal artery, middle meningeal vein and the meningeal (recurrent) branch of CN V3 which supplies the dura and contains sympathetic fibres (option D).

(option A). The foramen lacerum contains vessels (meningeal branch of ascending pharyngeal artery, emissary veins) and is otherwise occluded by fibrous issue and cartilage The Internal carotid artery passes along its superior surface but does not traverse it.

questions.text: Danger space of neck is situated between:
questions.solution:
BUCCOPHARYNGEAL FASCIA This fascia covers all the constrictor muscles externally and extends onto the superficial aspect of the buccinator muscle and is attached to pharyngeal tubercle. Retropharyngeal space lies posterior to buccopharyngeal fascia. Alar fascia is an ancillary layer of deep cervical fascia which divides retropharyngeal space into two parts. The posterior space between alar and prevertebral fasciae is the 'dangerous space in neck'.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes with sudden-onset vision loss in his left eye for one hour .He has a history of coronary artery disease, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Blood pressure is 145/80 mm Hg and pulse is 72/min. On examination, the patient can see only hand motions through the left eye Fundoscopic evaluation of the eye shows a cherry-red spot in the macula with surrounding retinal whitening .Cranial nerve examination is otherwise unremarkable. There is a left-sided neck bruit on cardiovascular examination. Which of the following is the most likely path of the embolus causing this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Retinal artery occlusion (RAO) is an important cause of acute, painless, monocular vision loss Thromboembolic complications of atherosclerosis in the internal carotid are the most common cause of RAO. The retinal artery is one of the first branches of the ophthalmic artery, which receives its supply from the internal carotid.

(Option A and C) There are a number of anastomoses between branches of the ophthalmic artery and branches of the external carotid, including the facial artery and temporal artery, but neither branch anastomoses with the retinal artery or supplies the retina.

(Option D) The anterior cerebral artery is a branch of the circle of Willis that supplies blood to the midline portions of the frontal and superior medial parietal lobes. Its occlusion can lead to loss of strength and sensation in the contralateral lower extremity, incontinence and transcortical motor aphasia.

Ref. BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 3

questions.text: Abdominal aorta giving testicular artery at what level of vertebra?
questions.solution:
The testicular artery is a branch of the abdominal aorta given off at the level of vertebra L2. It descends on the posterior abdominal wall to reach the deep inguinal ring where it enters the spermatic cord

Ref. BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 2

Section 2 ABDOMEN AND PELVIS Chapter 18 MALE EXTERNAL GENITAL ORGANS page no. 263

questions.text: Anterior boundary of inguinal canal is formed by muscles -
questions.solution:
Boundaries of inguinal canal :

  • Anterior – External oblique and internal oblique
  • Posterior – Transversalis fascia and conjoint tendon
  • Superior – Internal oblique and transversus abdominis
  • Inferior – Inguinal ligament

Ref. BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 2

Section 2 ABDOMEN AND PELVIS Chapter 2 ANTERIOR ABDOMINAL WALL page no. 249

choices.text: Above piriformis through Greater Sciatic Foramen
Below piriformis through Greater Sciatic Foramen

questions.text: Nerve involved in the given condition passes through-
questions.solution:
• Given condition in the image is lurching gait ( Trendelenburg sign positive).
  • Nerve involved in this condition is superior gluteal nerve which passes through greater sciatic foramen above piriformis.

Ref. BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 2

Section 2 ABDOMEN AND PELVIS Chapter 4 GLUTEAL REGION page no. 80 and 81

questions.text: Structure which passes through both greater and lesser sciatic foramen?
questions.solution:
Structures Passing through Greater Sciatic Foramen

Above Piriformis – Superior Gluteal nerve, artery and vein.

Below Piriformis – Inferior Gluteal nerve, artery and vein

-Nerve to Obturator Internus

-Nerve to Quadratus Femoris

-Sciatic Nerve

-Pudendal nerve

-Internal Pudendal artery and vein

-Nerve to obturator internus

Structures Passing through Lesser Sciatic Foramen

-Pudendal Nerve

-Internal Pudendal artery and vein 

-Obturator Internus muscle

-Nerve to obturator internus

Ref. BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 2

Section 2 ABDOMEN AND PELVIS Chapter 4 GLUTEAL REGION page no. 85

questions.text: Coracoid process is a kind of epiphysis
questions.solution:
Atavistic Epiphysis

Examples : Coracoid process of scapula and Ostrigonum

Ref. BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 1

Section 1 upper limb Chapter 2 bones page no. 9

questions.text: Root value of nerve involved in Meralgia paraesthesia is-
questions.solution:
• Nerve involved in meralgia paresthesia is lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh.
  • Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh originates from L2 and L3 and is entraped beneath the inguinal ligament in this condition.

Ref. BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 2

Section 1 lower limb Chapter FRONT OF THIGH page no. 56
